title: 1695-C
statement: C. Zero Pathtime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputYou are given a grid with $$$n$$$ rows and $$$m$$$ columns. We denote the square on the $$$i$$$-th ($$$1\\le i\\le n$$$) row and $$$j$$$-th ($$$1\\le j\\le m$$$) column by $$$(i, j)$$$ and the number there by $$$a_{ij}$$$. All numbers are equal to $$$1$$$ or to $$$-1$$$.You start from the square $$$(1, 1)$$$ and can move one square down or one square to the right at a time. In the end, you want to end up at the square $$$(n, m)$$$.Is it possible to move in such a way so that the sum of the values written in all the visited cells (including $$$a_{11}$$$ and $$$a_{nm}$$$) is $$$0$$$?InputEach test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \\leq t \\leq 10^4$$$). Description of the test cases follows.The first line of each test case contains two integers $$$n$$$ and $$$m$$$ ($$$1 \\le n, m \\le 1000$$$)  — the size of the grid.Each of the following $$$n$$$ lines contains $$$m$$$ integers. The $$$j$$$-th integer on the $$$i$$$-th line is $$$a_{ij}$$$ ($$$a_{ij} = 1$$$ or $$$-1$$$)  — the element in the cell $$$(i, j)$$$.It is guaranteed that the sum of $$$n\\cdot m$$$ over all test cases does not exceed $$$10^6$$$.OutputFor each test case, print "YES" if there exists a path from the top left to the bottom right that adds up to $$$0$$$, and "NO" otherwise. You can output each letter in any case.ExampleInput51 111 21 -11 41 -1 1 -13 41 -1 -1 -1-1 1 1 -11 1 1 -13 41 -1 1 1-1 1 -1 11 -1 1 1OutputNO YES YES YES NONoteOne possible path for the fourth test case is given in the picture in the statement.

processed.result:
You are given a grid of $n$ rows and $m$ columns. Each cell in the grid contains either a 1 or a -1. You start at the top left corner of the grid and can only move down or right. Your goal is to reach the bottom right corner of the grid. 

Determine if there is a path from the top left to the bottom right corner such that the sum of all the numbers you encounter along the path is 0.

**Input:**

* The first line contains the number of test cases, $t$.
* For each test case:
    * The first line contains two integers, $n$ and $m$, representing the number of rows and columns.
    * The following $n$ lines each contain $m$ integers, representing the values in each cell of the grid.

**Output:**

For each test case, print "YES" if a path with a sum of 0 exists, and "NO" otherwise.

You are given a grid of numbers, either 1 or -1. You start at the top left corner and can only move down or right.  Can you reach the bottom right corner by visiting cells so that the sum of all the numbers you visit is zero?
